turns.content:
I hope these suggestions have been helpful. Here are a few more ideas:

1. Use humor: Laughing and finding the humor in a situation can help shift your perspective and reduce negative thoughts.
2. Use physical touch: Physical touch, such as hugging or holding hands, can release feel-good hormones and reduce negative thoughts.
3. Seek out new experiences: Trying new things and stepping out of your comfort zone can help broaden your perspective and reduce negative thinking.
4. Use nature as a source of inspiration: Spending time in nature can help reduce stress and improve your mood, which can in turn reduce negative thinking.
5. Engage in creative activities: Creativity can be a great way to express yourself and shift your focus away from negative thoughts.

I hope these suggestions have been helpful. Here are a few more ideas:

1. Engage in activities that you enjoy: Doing things that you find fulfilling and enjoyable can help improve your mood and reduce negative thoughts.
2. Seek out activities that promote physical and emotional well-being: This can include things like yoga, tai chi, or other forms of exercise that promote a sense of calm and well-being.
3. Seek out positive role models: Surrounding yourself with people who are positive and supportive can help you develop a more positive outlook.
4. Seek social support: Surrounding yourself with supportive friends and family members can help you feel more positive and less isolated.
5. Practice self-compassion: Be kind and understanding with yourself, and try to treat yourself the way you would treat a good friend. This can help reduce negative self-talk and negative thinking.

Yes, here are a few more suggestions:

1. Use humor: Laughing and finding the humor in a situation can help shift your perspective and reduce negative thoughts.
2. Use physical touch: Physical touch, such as hugging or holding hands, can release feel-good hormones and reduce negative thoughts.
3. Seek out new experiences: Trying new things and stepping out of your comfort zone can help broaden your perspective and reduce negative thinking.
4. Use nature as a source of inspiration: Spending time in nature can help reduce stress and improve your mood, which can in turn reduce negative thinking.
5. Engage in creative activities: Creativity can be a great way to express yourself and shift your focus away from negative thoughts.

Here are a few more books that may be helpful:

* "The Alchemist" by Paulo Coelho
* "The Art of Loving" by Erich Fromm
* "The Success Principles" by Jack Canfield
* "Feel the Fear and Do It Anyway" by Susan Jeffers
* "The Road Less Traveled" by M. Scott Peck
* "Man's Search for Meaning" by Viktor Frankl
* "Awaken the Giant Within" by Tony Robbins
* "The Art of Happiness" by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler
* "The Seven Spiritual Laws of Success" by Deepak Chopra
* "The Untethered Soul" by Michael A. Singer

Again, these are just a few examples, and there are many other books that could be helpful as well. It may be helpful to look for books that address specific areas that you would like to work on, such as positive thinking, stress management, or building self-confidence.

what 25 books on the subject would be particularly helpful for an African-American to read

Here are 25 books that may be particularly helpful for an African-American to read:

1. "The Autobiography of Malcolm X" by Malcolm X
2. "The Souls of Black Folk" by W.E.B. Du Bois
3. "Between the World and Me" by Ta-Nehisi Coates
4. "Black Boy" by Richard Wright
5. "Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave" by Frederick Douglass
6. "The Color Purple" by Alice Walker
7. "Invisible Man" by Ralph Ellison
8. "Go Tell It on the Mountain" by James Baldwin
9. "The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness" by Michelle Alexander
10. "The Fire Next Time" by James Baldwin
11. "The Warmth of Other Suns" by Isabel Wilkerson
12. "The Devil Finds Work" by James Baldwin
13. "No Name in the Street" by James Baldwin
14. "Maud Martha" by Gwendolyn Brooks
15. "The Crisis of the Negro Intellectual" by Harold Cruse
16. "The African American Experience" by Alton Hornsby Jr.
17. "The House That Race Built" edited by Wahneema Lubiano
18. "The Miseducation of the Negro" by Carter G. Woodson
19. "The Agreement" by Elmer G. Hom
